website_summaries.verdict: The best budget seatpost tube for a wide variety of bicycle types and sizes.
pros: Heavy-duty construction makes this seatpost perfect for extreme sport bicycles like BMX and downhill gravity riding
Long length offers plenty of room for height adjustment
cons: Thicker tubing may be too big for some older, vintage bicycle frames

customer_reviews.title: Fit store bought kids bike perfectly.
customer_reviews.text: I needed a longer bike seat pole for my 6 year old she is very tall and her bike was pretty much brand new. I had gotten her a store bought Frozen bike with training wheels. I was nervous about what would work because I don't know anything about bike seats, poles how to measure the width etc. But it fit perfectly. It was easy to replace the old pole out. She was able to ride without training wheels and without hurting her knees. I also didn't have to go out and buy a whole new bike which was super.
customer_reviews.author: diana

customer_reviews.title: Excellent!
customer_reviews.text: Perfect replacement for my Huffy Cranbrook 9 1/2" seatpost. I have long legs and needed at least two more inches on my seat height. This seatpost is perfect. My rides are now much more smooth, and hills are less of a battle.
customer_reviews.author: Stan Blackburn

customer_reviews.title: I also put this on a Cranbrook.
customer_reviews.text: This seat post is plenty long. I read a review about someone putting it on a cranbrook and so I did the same seeing as it was the right size. Taller bike riders essentially require this.
customer_reviews.author: Tyrell

customer_reviews.title: Another Happy Long-Legged Bicyclist
customer_reviews.text: Surprisingly tight tolerances (within a few mils) for such an economical tall seat post. This has made all the difference for me on my vintage around-town ten speed bicycle. Being a lanky light-weight, I can't "weigh in" on load capacity, but it should easily handle any reasonable non-abusive load to which it is subjected.
customer_reviews.author: DT

customer_reviews.title: Nice tight fit into the seat tube as well
customer_reviews.text: I needed an inexpensive steel seat post for a cheap steel bike with a 19-inch frame, which came with a 300mm post that was a few inches short of my optimum saddle position. What I got was a inexpensive steel post for my cheap steel bike that allowed me to raise the seat by a few inches. Nice tight fit into the seat tube as well. Not much else to say, it is well made and finished, it fits the bill and is made in the USA. The only strange thing is that the seat post is not marked with the diameter, but really who cares.
customer_reviews.author: SeventeenSeventySix

customer_reviews.title: Great product!
customer_reviews.text: Fit my standard bicycle. Used this to replace my seat. It's a bit longer than the standard/avg bicycle post, which worked out great since I'm taller. I can now adjust my seat a bit higher and be more comfortable. Can also sit lower like a normal post if needed. Highly recommend. It's a metal rod ... not much to say other than it works, it's shiny and I like it. :)
customer_reviews.author: BumbleBeeTuna

customer_reviews.title: Nice replacement
customer_reviews.text: I didn't realize there were different size seat posts for bikes but not surprised either. It seems to be well made. Fastened it to the seat and slid it into the frame, tightened it down and I'm off. Pretty simple. Just make sure to measure to verify it will fit and you shouldn't have any issues as far as fit.
customer_reviews.author: CPTNFNTSC

customer_reviews.title: You don't need shorter legs; just a longer seat post.
customer_reviews.text: This Wald 901-15 seat post is as strong as my original an enabled me to properly extend my legs and apply more pressure to the peddles. What a difference as little as 2 1/2 " can make!

customer_reviews.title: Great to extend kids bike seat

customer_reviews.title: Make sure you know your seat post size!
customer_reviews.text: Works as advertised. My only issue is that I assumed bike seat posts were standard sizes and they are not, so the 1" part of this ended up being a bit too narrow in diameter for my bike (which apparently is 25.7mm). I used a sheet metal shim to make up the difference.

customer_reviews.title: Is as it should be
customer_reviews.text: This one is hard to mess up. It is 1” at the wide part and 7/8” at the thin part as advertised. I didn’t measure the length but it should be correct. We just needed a taller post for the six year old’s 12” bike, ended up cutting an inch off to make it work. Little guy has a new bike coming for his birthday. This hand-me-down trainer just needed a bit more height to be comfortable until then. One other thing, there is a nifty safety line so you don’t over extend the height. And it is chrome steel, so not for weight reduction for races but plenty strong.
customer_reviews.author: H. Stewart
